newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU official does not rule out wheat tax cut soon.
newsitem.headline: EU official does not rule out wheat tax cut soon.

text.p: A European Union official familiar with grain exports said on Thursday he did not rule out a cut in the EU's recently imposed tax on wheat exports.

Any cut would be driven by a drop in world prices since the 15 Ecu per tonne tax was introduced earlier this month, but the official could not say whether this would be on the agenda for weekly EU grain talks later on Thursday.
Traders say such a move would hardly be unexpected since wheat prices have swung lower since the Commission overrode French opposition to introduce the tax on May 14.

Although EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler has been quoted as saying the tax is necessary in the face of higher U.S. hard red winter prices, traders say a more suitable benchmark remains the cheaper soft red winter which the EU traditionally follows, and the tax is therefore out of line.

However, some analysts believe the EU will be cautious about doing anything that might signal it is ready to start looking at world wheat markets again, when it has said it wants to use the tax as a dissuasive measure to block exports for the time being.
"In a way it would be worse to reduce it to five or 10 (Ecus) than to leave it where it is or just scrap it," one said.
An EU grain trade source told Reuters in Brussels the tax no longer reflected market realities and should be cut.
The taxes currently stand at 15 Ecus per tonne for soft wheat and 20 Ecus per tonne for soft wheat flour.
